> > Suppose you wrote the sort methods. That means that they have tests,
> > and damn good ones. As a result, a method like this can't break on its
> > own:
> >
> > if myCollection.size < 20
> >     myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.bubbleSort)
> > else if myCollection.size < 100
> >     myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.quickSort)
> > else
> >     myCollection.sortWith(SortAlgorithms.mergeSort)
> > end
> 
> There's a way the method can break: e.g. if the merge sort implementation
> does not work with collections under a certain size (precondition) 
> and the threshold in the sort method was chosen incorrectly. 

This is a very fine line, Johannes. It is reasonable to assume that a sort 
method, in general, works on collections of any size; otherwise, it should be 
named something other than "sort". Perhaps it should be 
named "sortCollectionsOfSizeLessThanTwenty". This is a design issue; not a 
testing issue.

If the bubbleSort algorithm doesn't work with collections smaller than twenty 
items, then it's bubbleSort that's broken, not this method. That was my 
original point.

> Or the changed
> implementation of merge sort changed the threshold. The underlying 
> pre- and postconditions can change without noticing as long as they 
> are not formalized and proven to hold.

I don't think these are likely to happen in a sort method. The underlying 
assumption I made is that "sort" works: that is, it works for any collection 
of any size and any kinds of objects that can be compared with each other for 
ordering. If that's not true, then I would probably need Learning Tests to 
codify the unexpected pre- and post-conditions -- those would be tests on the 
sort algorithms, though, and not necessarily on my method. :)

If I really needed to test my method, I'd change the design so that the sort 
algorithms can easily be mocked; then I'd write tests that ensured that the 
method tried to call the appropriate sort algorithm on the appropriate 
conditions.

> But probably you are right and the sort example is not as good as I thought
> in the beginning. So I declare myself defeated until I come up with 
> an example that makes sense as is and not only when considered in an 
> abstract way.

I'm happy to see it when you come up with it. I don't always practice what I 
preach, because I'm not good enough at it yet. More examples to try to 
understand would help. :) I just notice a bunch of duplicated tests in my 
current projects; I'd like to remove that duplication.
